meta.interest: [2025-08-05] We are tracking AI labor solutions for logistics and trucking recruitment but do not find current approaches compelling. We prefer logistics infrastructure plays with broader applicability beyond driver churn reduction.

[2025-08-05] Really excited about robotics, especially in industrial settings where safety is critical
.

[2025-08-05] While we see potential in the home health or industrial robotics space, we are concerned about go-to-market challenges, vertical-specific sales processes, and the lack of commercially ready traction. Armstrong's dishwasher robot highlighted for us the difficulty of scaling robotics technology due to training complexity, despite its long-term potential.
.

[2025-08-05] We're excited about robotics and sensor-native foundation models as a wedge into the physical world. Archetype, building a foundation model for the physical world via multimodal sensor data, stood out for its enterprise traction and generalizable safety/compliance applications. We are particularly interested in platforms that abstract physical sensor data into programmable intelligence, as a path to robotics software scale. However, we are sensitive to round dynamics and will push for structured entry (e.g., discount to A or interim rounds).
.

[2025-08-05] We continue to prioritize frontier robotics with real unit economic leverage and software advantage. Veer Robotics (facade-cleaning robots) fits squarely in our robotics thesis: replacing high-risk manual labor with vertically-integrated automation that also captures unique inspection data. We're sensitive to capital efficiency, leasing models, and software data upsell opportunities. Preference for teams transitioning from semi-autonomous to fully autonomous over time.
.

[2025-08-05] We continue to track vertical robotics that replace dangerous and repetitive manual labor, especially where recurring leasing models and inspection data upsells can drive software margins. Hardware reliability, unit economics (multi-robot per operator), and defensibility beyond suction/IP remain key diligence points. Sensitive to lack of frontier VC traction.

[2025-07-29] We are actively tracking foundational infrastructure for robotics — from simulation platforms to real-time operating systems — as critical enablers of the next wave of physical AI. Startups like Foxglove and Xronos that abstract complexity in robot development and deployment align well with our belief in verticalized automation with software leverage..
meta.thesis: Physical AI: Robotic Applications and Foundational Infra

[2025-08-28] We remain cautious on sales tax automation platforms at later-stage valuations. While regulatory tailwinds create urgency, the market is likely to consolidate into one or two winners. We will not pursue late-stage entries unless we have a differentiated wedge or asymmetric entry point.

[2025-08-07] We discussed companies like Vadera Labs and others in AI-driven appraisals for niche markets (e.g., collectibles, industrial equipment). These markets are interesting to us, but we see challenges in validation, scalability, and market size that limit their appeal.
.

[2025-08-05] We are excited about AI legal tech platforms focused on negotiation and deal optimization for operators, not just lawyers. We prefer tools that replace legal process fees with revenue-generating AI services (e.g., automated term sheet negotiation, contract optimization for GCs and CROs).
.

[2025-07-30] We are interested in legal tech, but skeptical of generic tooling plays. We prefer verticalized legal platforms focused on specific high-volume categories (e.g., small claims, insurance defense) where AI replaces human workflow. Selling to GCs or law firms directly remains difficult unless there's a deeply embedded GTM edge or AI-native operational model. We are more excited about full-stack AI law firms than horizontal legal SaaS.
.

[2025-07-29] We’re excited about AI-native commerce infrastructure — from agentic shopping assistants to intelligent procurement and recommence platforms. Companies like Fermat and Coupa exemplify our interest in replacing fragmented stacks with adaptive systems that personalize experiences, optimize supply chains, and support circular consumption models..
meta.caution: Has to be a strong wedge against legacy players and a clear vertical focus.

meta.interest: Interested in infrastructure that enables new forms of transaction logic from dynamic pricing to alternative payments and payment acceptance in underserved markets. We are seeing underserved export markets emerge as fintech infrastructure opportunities, especially when compliance and onboarding are automated using AI. We're looking for fintech infra companies that can build end-to-end export platforms and monetize risk, data, or workflow layers. Margins, take rates, and use-case expansion (e.g., cards, treasury) matter.
meta.caution: Pure payment orchestration or Stripe clones with no clear wedge or vertical focus are a pass. Low take-rate, commoditized rails are also unattractive unless paired with monetizable adjacencies.

meta.interest:
[2025-09-17] We are tracking digital metal service centers modernizing U.S. re-industrialization. Filters: instant quoting adoption, supply contracts with mills, and SKU-level telemetry feeding predictive procurement.
.

meta.interest: New subcategory created for deal announcements. Generated on 2025-09-17.. [2025-09-22] We are tracking restaurant and hospitality infrastructure platforms aiming to bypass aggregators (DoorDash, Uber Eats) and return margin/data control to operators. Embedding menus across new distribution surfaces (fuel apps, food discovery platforms, etc.) creates potential for new revenue channels. Filters: founder ability to scale restaurant onboarding rapidly, potential to expand beyond restaurants into broader fragmented services, and opportunity to build data/financial products on top of transaction flow. Risks: historically slow and difficult sector, delivery/logistics remain outsourced, and low per-order pricing may cap upside.. meta.interest:
[2025-09-17] We are not pursuing AI-enabled real-time medical interpretation. Strong need, but technical accuracy and liability bar is high, and incumbents with human interpreters already hold distribution.

[2025-09-08] We are interested in AI pathology platforms that go beyond diagnostics to stratify patients and accelerate clinical trials (e.g., bone marrow disease imaging). Filters: pharma partnerships, regulatory clarity, mechanistic depth.
.

portfolio.brief_description: AI urgent care coordination platform for healthcare

meta.interest:
[2025-08-19] We are not interested in diagnostic-heavy healthcare businesses that rely on daily patient engagement and physician push — adoption and integration hurdles remain too high.
. [2025-08-26] We remain cautious on local family-care and caregiver marketplaces. Despite clear need on both sides, marketplace liquidity is regional, margins are capped by human labor, and historical attempts (care.com, trusted) have struggled to scale. The opportunity may lie in caregiver empowerment (education, upskilling) rather than pure matching.

meta.interest:
[2025-09-17] We are not pursuing early healthcare workflow tools (e.g. Dakota Health). Vertical insurance/clinical sales remain slow and feature-like rather than platform-scale.
.

[2025-08-05] We remain interested in healthcare data workflow tools but are cautious about companies pitching AI solutions that are too broad or generic (e.g., "AI for doctors" chatbots). We prefer narrow, specialty-specific approaches with clear go-to-market plans and measurable outcomes, such as urology or cardiology-focused systems.
.

[2025-08-05] We are tracking companies building AI tools for tumor boards and oncology decision-making but are concerned about unclear data monetization strategies and the risk of being commoditized by broader AI offerings from incumbents.
.

[2025-08-05] We believe a new category will emerge at the intersection of wearables, calendaring, and agentic task automation, turning passive health data into actionable workflows. Consumer GTM remains challenging; we look for teams with deep product DNA and data orchestration strategies that can avoid becoming a point solution.
.

[2025-08-05] We are passing on consultancy-like AI platforms that target clinical trial design simulations unless there’s a clear wedge into automating regulatory workflows or replacing legacy software systems. The market opportunity lies in replacing human-run simulation studies, not in incremental design tools.....

[2025-08-11] We are tracking companies building AI tools for tumor boards and oncology decision-making but are concerned about unclear data monetization strategies and the risk of being commoditized by broader AI offerings from incumbents.

meta.interest: [2025-08-19] We believe a new category will emerge at the intersection of wearables, calendaring, and agentic task automation, turning passive health data into actionable workflows. Consumer GTM remains challenging; we look for teams with deep product DNA and data orchestration strategies that can avoid becoming a point solution.

[2025-09-22] We remain cautious on early medical malpractice automation startups. Second Look highlights a large market (frequent litigation, high claims volume) where AI could meaningfully accelerate adjudication and settlement prediction. However, current team and product execution are weak, and physician-led efforts without strong AI depth lack defensibility. Filters: insurance claim categories with repetitive patterns (malpractice, small claims, auto liability). We will revisit if stronger technical founders emerge.. meta.interest: [2025-08-19] We remain interested in healthcare fraud prevention and payer data infrastructure, where $300B+ in leakage creates a structural wedge. The most promising angle is unifying fragmented payer data to improve Medicare Advantage star ratings and reimbursement. Filters: ability to integrate across disparate data sources, targeted entry points in high-value claims flows, and proof of ROI for plans. We remain cautious of horizontal platforms without a clear disease- or claims-specific wedge.

meta.interest:
[2025-08-05] We are excited about AI-driven drug discovery platforms that combine proprietary multimodal datasets with generative biology and experimental feedback loops. We prefer companies building multi-shot therapeutic engines rather than single-asset biotech plays.
.

[2025-08-05] We are NOT interested in pure biotech companies focused on single therapies or per-patient personalized therapeutics unless there is a clearly differentiated techbio platform component. We are cautious about the scalability and regulatory complexity of personalized cancer vaccines and per-patient biologics manufacturing.
.

[2025-08-05] We are interested in biologics manufacturing optimization and biomanufacturing infrastructure, especially where AI improves biologic production efficiency (e.g., CHO cells, CAR-T manufacturing, active control cells). However, we are mindful of geopolitical risks in biomanufacturing supply chains and the competitive landscape in Asia.
.

[2025-08-05] We are not investing in biotech plays without a techbio wedge. We passed on companies like Neosplice due to lack of commercial clarity, academic founder posture, and regulatory/scientific risk. Even in cases where there is scientific promise, we look for compelling software leverage, differentiated datasets, and go-to-market plans that avoid single-asset development traps.

meta.interest:
[2025-09-17] We are interested in synthetic biology applied to drug inputs (e.g., microbe-produced heparin, oligosaccharides). This represents an overlooked drug modality with geopolitical and safety tailwinds; key diligence is cost parity and scalability.
.

[2025-09-08] We are tracking AI-first genomic design platforms. COVID validated mRNA delivery; the unlock is now sequence optimization and proprietary synthetic data generation. Filters: full wet-lab loop (not just annotations), ability to build a defensible data moat, and technical founders with pharma traction.
.

[2025-09-08] We are interested in biotech opportunities where regulatory or supply chain risk creates urgency (e.g. replacing Chinese pig-derived inputs). These can attract non-dilutive funding and government support if technically validated.

[2025-08-28] We are excited about AI-driven drug discovery platforms that combine proprietary multimodal datasets with generative biology and experimental feedback loops. We prefer companies building multi-shot therapeutic engines rather than single-asset biotech plays.
.

[2025-08-28] We are NOT interested in pure biotech companies focused on single therapies or per-patient personalized therapeutics unless there is a clearly differentiated techbio platform component. We are cautious about the scalability and regulatory complexity of personalized cancer vaccines and per-patient biologics manufacturing.
.

[2025-08-28] We are interested in biologics manufacturing optimization and biomanufacturing infrastructure, especially where AI improves biologic production efficiency (e.g., CHO cells, CAR-T manufacturing, active control cells). However, we are mindful of geopolitical risks in biomanufacturing supply chains and the competitive landscape in Asia.
.

[2025-08-28] We are interested in biologics manufacturing enablement platforms that apply AI to cell manipulation and process optimization, targeting bottlenecks in scaling therapeutic production. The market is large, driven by the dominance of biologics in top-selling drugs. Key filters: defensible manufacturing IP, penetration into pharma/CMO supply chains, and ability to win in high-capex, scale-driven markets. We remain cautious on customer concentration in Asia without clear U.S. market access.
.

[2025-08-28] We are interested in AI-driven lab platforms that close the loop between image-based phenotyping, multi-omics readouts, and hypothesis generation to accelerate oncology drug discovery. The opportunity lies in combining high-throughput experimental feedback with predictive models to identify novel mechanisms in a fraction of traditional timelines. Filters: strength of founding team across ML and wet lab execution, ability to generate proprietary datasets, and clear differentiation from existing image-omics players.
.

[2025-08-26] We are interested in AI-native lab platforms targeting synthesis bottlenecks in drug discovery. Natural-language-to-experiment design connected to robotic execution could compress timelines by orders of magnitude. Timing is favorable as LLMs now reason over chemistry reliably. Filters: proprietary integration into lab workflows, quality of pharma partnerships, and pace of execution. Defensibility must extend beyond access to LLMs.
....... [2025-09-22] We are tracking synthetic biology companies with targeted commercial applications (e.g. synthetic heparin as pig-derived alternative). Filters: mission-critical drug supply chains, regulatory support, and potential for government-backed procurement. Risk: synthetic bio has fallen out of VC favor post-Ginkgo; requires clear differentiation as application-first, not platform-first.. [2025-09-22] We remain cautious on “platform-first” synthetic biology pitches without a clear commercial target. Market currently values therapeutics delivered, not the R&D platforms behind them.. [2025-09-22] We remain cautious on “platform-first” synthetic biology pitches without a clear commercial target. Market currently values therapeutics delivered, not the R&D platforms behind them.. [2025-09-22] We are interested in biotech opportunities where regulatory or supply chain risk creates urgency (e.g. replacing Chinese pig-derived inputs). These can attract non-dilutive funding and government support if technically validated.. [2025-09-22] We are interested in biotech opportunities where regulatory or supply chain risk creates urgency (e.g. replacing Chinese pig-derived inputs). These can attract non-dilutive funding and government support if technically validated.. [2025-09-22] We remain cautious on synthetic bio “platform-first” pitches. Portool’s squeeze-cell modality is technically impressive but suffers from unclear in vivo validation, weak DNA delivery, and uncertain defensibility against electroporation incumbents. Market currently values therapeutics and validated assays, not delivery platforms with speculative bedside visions.. [2025-09-22] We remain cautious on bio-based sustainable dye platforms. Lite-1 engineers microbes to produce non-toxic dyes, addressing petrochemical incumbency in textiles, food, and cosmetics. Team has laid a thoughtful scientific foundation, but progress is still early (11 LOIs, no pilots converted), with high execution and scale-up risk. Filters: regulatory tailwinds banning toxic dyes, consumer pressure on brands, synthetic biology cost reductions. Risks: commodity price equivalence, long timelines, limited VC appetite post-Ginkgo. Track for later but likely pass absent a strong lead.We are interested in synthetic bio companies targeting mission-critical drug inputs. Cellco is developing bio-synthetic heparin to replace pig-derived supply chains. Filters: essential drugs with fragile global supply, regulatory and geopolitical support (e.g., Middle East LPs seeking national security resilience), potential for hospital partnerships. Risks: long development timelines, capital intensity, dependence on regulatory milestones. Attractive differentiated “application-first” synthetic bio play versus platform-first peers.

meta.description: TechBio companies apply advanced computational methods — including machine learning, simulation, and high-throughput data generation — to accelerate discovery, design, and development in life sciences. Unlike traditional biotech, which typically carries binary FDA risk and long development cycles, TechBio firms often monetize earlier through platform licensing, SaaS-like models, or data/insight sales. Core themes include AI-driven drug discovery, synthetic biology design platforms, lab automation, and molecular simulation infrastructure.

meta.interest: [2025-08-28] We remain cautious on local family-care and caregiver marketplaces. Despite clear need on both sides, marketplace liquidity is regional, margins are capped by human labor, and historical attempts (care.com, trusted) have struggled to scale. The opportunity may lie in caregiver empowerment (education, upskilling) rather than pure matching.

meta.interest: [2025-07-29] We are excited about agentic infrastructure, but cautious around horizontal B2B SaaS without clear fintech or commerce applications.: While platforms like Roya (commercial agent orchestration) and RTXEN (agentic FinOps OS) show promise, our core value-add is stronger when there is a verticalized GTM, such as fintech or commerce. We prefer use cases where orchestration layers have clear commercial outputs or data feedback loops, not generic dashboards or BI tools. We're also mindful of intense early competition and commoditization in agent infra.. [2025-09-22] We are tracking fintech infrastructure that embeds equipment or asset financing at the point of sale. Fragmented workflows create opportunities for agentic financing platforms that streamline underwriting and distribution. Filters: distribution secured via OEMs or vertical SaaS, defensibility beyond simple capital provision, and ability to scale efficiently in fragmented verticals. Risks: timing of adoption, capital intensity, and risk of adverse selection if distribution is not locked in early.. [2025-09-22] We are tracking fintech infrastructure that embeds equipment or asset financing at the point of sale. meta.thesis: Stablecoins: Emerging Global Payment Rail and Financial Platform
meta.interest: [2025-07-30] Export-focused fintech (e.g., Shield) is interesting if paired with AI and infrastructure plays. We are seeing underserved export markets emerge as fintech infrastructure opportunities, especially when compliance and onboarding are automated using AI. We're looking for fintech infra companies that can build end-to-end export platforms and monetize risk, data, or workflow layers. Margins, take rates, and use-case expansion (e.g., cards, treasury) matter.

meta.description: Core transaction processing platforms including acquiring, gateways, payment APIs, orchestration layers, and ledger infra.
meta.interest:
[2025-08-28] We are interested in payment infrastructure for the next generation of AI-native and no-code businesses, especially tools that simplify Stripe integration, real-time reconciliation, usage-based billing, and global compliance. We need to validate that these solutions are defensible and not easily replicated by incumbents.

[2025-08-05] Export-focused fintech (e.g., Shield) is interesting if paired with AI and infrastructure plays. We are seeing underserved export markets emerge as fintech infrastructure opportunities, especially when compliance and onboarding are automated using AI. We're looking for fintech infra companies that can build end-to-end export platforms and monetize risk, data, or workflow layers. Margins, take rates, and use-case expansion (e.g., cards, treasury) matter.
.
meta.caution: Avoid generic Stripe clones without pricing, routing, or market edge.

meta.interest:
[2025-09-17] We are tracking AI-enabled financial routing layers that unify invoicing, payments (including stablecoins), and trade documentation into a single workflow. In an environment of shifting tariffs and multi-country sourcing, a platform that embeds tax, duties, and payment logic directly into AP could meaningfully compress working capital cycles. Filters: vertical depth, compliance readiness, and potential to replace legacy providers (Pagero, Melio) rather than sit beside them.
.

[2025-09-08] We are tracking new AI-native billing and payments platforms. meta.description: B2B and B2C platforms handling FX, remittances, treasury routing, and compliance in cross-border payments.
meta.interest:
Excited about seamless FX orchestration, especially for SMBs and global SaaS platforms.. [2025-08-11] Export-focused fintech (e.g., Shield) is interesting if paired with AI and infrastructure plays. We are seeing underserved export markets emerge as fintech infrastructure opportunities, especially when compliance and onboarding are automated using AI. We're looking for fintech infra companies that can build end-to-end export platforms and monetize risk, data, or workflow layers. Margins, take rates, and use-case expansion (e.g., cards, treasury) matter.
. [2025-08-11] We are interested in B2B cross-border payments platforms combining regulated banking infrastructure with stablecoin settlement rails. Integration into local real-time payment systems (e.g., Brazil’s PICS) plus multi-currency named accounts and FX liquidity APIs creates high switching costs for enterprise customers. Key filters: regulatory moat, stablecoin + fiat settlement in one platform, and enterprise adoption in emerging markets. We are sensitive to heavy early revenue concentration.
meta.caution: Hard to compete on cost/FX spread unless paired with workflow or data moat.

meta.interest:
[2025-08-28] Export-focused fintech (e.g., Shield) is interesting if paired with AI and infrastructure plays. We are seeing underserved export markets emerge as fintech infrastructure opportunities, especially when compliance and onboarding are automated using AI. We're looking for fintech infra companies that can build end-to-end export platforms and monetize risk, data, or workflow layers. Margins, take rates, and use-case expansion (e.g., cards, treasury) matter.
.

[2025-08-28] We are interested in B2B cross-border payments platforms combining regulated banking infrastructure with stablecoin settlement rails. Integration into local real-time payment systems (e.g., Brazil’s PICS) plus multi-currency named accounts and FX liquidity APIs creates high switching costs for enterprise customers. Key filters: regulatory moat, stablecoin + fiat settlement in one platform, and enterprise adoption in emerging markets. We are sensitive to heavy early revenue concentration.
.

[2025-08-28] We are interested in stablecoin-based cross-border payment platforms, particularly those embedding compliance orchestration and enterprise payout rails rather than just consumer wallets. The opportunity lies in meeting migrant workers at the point of income and keeping flows digital (USD wallets, bill pay, card rails) to reduce cash-out leakage. Filters: proven compliance architecture, enterprise distribution, and retention of funds in-system. We remain cautious on crowdedness of the space and the risk that trust-rich incumbents capture share.

meta.description: Covers payment infrastructure using stablecoins, on-chain settlement networks, cross-border FX via crypto rails, and programmable finance layers.
meta.interest:
[2025-08-05] We are interested in infrastructure for stablecoin-based treasury management and corporate payments, particularly for European and global use cases. We are mindful of US regulatory hurdles for yield-generating stablecoin products.
.

[2025-08-05] Stablecoin infrastructure is a core emerging theme. We believe the market is bifurcating into (1) orchestration platforms for global, programmable money movement (e.g., DO, Wallapay) and (2) enterprise-grade stablecoin treasury management for corporates (e.g., Crypto, Velocity). We are open to placing multiple bets in both categories. We look for strong global licensing footprints, enterprise traction, and Stripe-level developer experiences. Founders with Revolut/Worldpay-style DNA are a plus. Regulatory defensibility and speed of GTM execution will determine winners.

[2025-07-30] We are actively tracking stablecoin-based FX and cross-border payment orchestration platforms like DO and Crypto/Fipto. We're particularly interested in infrastructure that abstracts on-chain complexity while unlocking speed and cost advantages over traditional rails..
meta.caution: We are cautious of consumer-facing crypto payment apps without regulatory clarity, enterprise traction, or clear advantages over traditional options.

meta.description: APIs and platforms that embed insurance into other platforms (e.g. travel, ecommerce, logistics, healthcare), often at the point of purchase or risk.
meta.interest: We are interested in embedded insurance where distribution is owned and the product design fits the host platform. Strong GTM and underwriting integration is key.
meta.caution: Avoid white-labeled integrations with no control over product or distribution.

meta.description: Next-gen managing general agents or full-stack insurers using tech to underwrite, price, and distribute niche or novel risk products.
meta.interest: We're open to digital MGAs if they demonstrate novel data advantages or target high-LTV underserved segments.
meta.caution: Cautious of high loss ratios or capital-intensive balance sheet exposure.

meta.description: Platforms offering AI-based underwriting, risk modeling, parametric pricing engines, or alternative data for actuarial decisioning.
meta.interest: Interested in infra that plugs into carriers or MGAs, especially where it unlocks new products or improves loss ratios.
meta.caution: Need strong defensibility via data or proprietary models.

meta.description: Tools to digitize claims processing, fraud detection, document intake, or adjuster workflows.
meta.interest: We’re interested in AI-first approaches that reduce time to payout or improve fraud detection with verifiable performance.
meta.caution: Avoid service-heavy or RPA-only models without vertical differentiation.

meta.description: Covers novel forms of insurance enabled by new data sources, behaviors, or product structures — including usage-based, creator economy, climate-linked, or digitally native coverage models.
meta.interest:
We're interested in risk products that go beyond traditional lines — where there's defensible GTM, underwriting clarity, and underserved demand. Bonus for parametric or behavior-driven models.. [2025-07-30] We see potential in niche insurance categories like high-end auto, motorcycle, and underutilized assets where traditional carriers misprice risk. We are cautious about consumer auto insurance startups targeting "high-risk drivers" due to underwriting profitability concerns.
. [2025-08-05] We see potential in niche insurance categories like high-end auto, motorcycle, and underutilized assets where traditional carriers misprice risk. We are cautious about consumer auto insurance startups targeting "high-risk drivers" due to underwriting profitability concerns.
meta.caution: Needs regulatory clarity and clear economic advantage vs incumbent products.

meta.description: Event-triggered or binary insurance products designed for specific domains like travel delays, weather events, or logistics failures.
meta.interest: Excited about parametric models with automated payout and clear coverage logic. Particularly relevant in climate, travel, and supply chain.

meta.description: Insurance tied to environmental data, carbon intensity, or sustainability-linked outcomes. Often relevant in agriculture, logistics, and construction.
meta.interest: Tracking platforms where ESG risk is priced transparently and productized in ways that match real-world financial incentives.
meta.caution: Regulatory clarity and data integrity are essential.

meta.description: Products and infra to underwrite cyber risk, digital asset custodianship, or smart contract insurance.
meta.interest: Tracking the evolution of cyber underwriting and security-data-powered policies. Could intersect with enterprise SaaS or on-chain infra.
meta.caution: Cyber is crowded — requires real differentiation in either GTM or data.

meta.thesis: The Promise of AI and Accounting
meta.interest:
[2025-08-26] We continue to track AI-driven accounting and tax automation. Regulatory complexity, CPA shortages, and data fragmentation create a strong wedge. The opportunity is in nuanced workflows (depreciation schedules, K-1 handling) that require expert-level judgment, not just rule encoding. Filters: access to proprietary training data via top firms, founder depth in accounting/tax, and trust with enterprise customers. We remain cautious on solutions without clear differentiation from incumbents like Intuit.

[2025-08-11] Agentic FinOps is a category we want to track closely. We believe there will be winners in building intelligent OS layers for CFOs and financial operations. However, we are looking for founders with high focus, strong velocity, and clear wedge entry into specific financial workflows. Broad, unfocused product surfaces are red flags. We are open to going early in this space with the right team.
.

[2025-08-28] Agentic FinOps is a category we want to track closely. We believe there will be winners in building intelligent OS layers for CFOs and financial operations. However, we are looking for founders with high focus, strong velocity, and clear wedge entry into specific financial workflows. Broad, unfocused product surfaces are red flags. We are open to going early in this space with the right team.
.

[2025-08-28] We continue to track AI-driven accounting and tax automation. Regulatory complexity, CPA shortages, and data fragmentation create a strong wedge. The opportunity is in nuanced workflows (depreciation schedules, K-1 handling) that require expert-level judgment, not just rule encoding. Filters: access to proprietary training data via top firms, founder depth in accounting/tax, and trust with enterprise customers. We remain cautious on solutions without clear differentiation from incumbents like Intuit.

[2025-08-26] We are tracking AI agents for accounting operations, starting with accrual/expense management in firms like Deloitte. Strong net revenue retention is encouraging; wedge lies in forward-deployed engineers and workflow automation.
.

meta.interest:
[2025-08-07] We reviewed Falcon, which offers an embedded platform for banks to combat scams and fraud. However, we find its technical complexity and differentiation from existing solutions like Careful to be unclear. While there is early traction, it feels to us like a point solution with uncertain scalability.

[2025-08-05] We discussed companies like Velocity Payments and others in fintech fraud prevention. We remain interested in the fintech space but are cautious about overlapping solutions and scalability challenges.
.

[2025-08-05] We are cautious about fintech fraud orchestration dashboards that aggregate existing point solutions without solving for core fraud detection (e.g., synthetic fraud). We prefer AI-driven risk mitigation systems that directly address fraud vectors.

We prefer use cases where orchestration layers have clear commercial outputs or data feedback loops, not generic dashboards or BI tools. We're also mindful of intense early competition and commoditization in agent infra.

meta.interest:
Excited about seamless FX orchestration, especially for SMBs and global SaaS platforms.. [2025-08-11] Export-focused fintech (e.g., Shield) is interesting if paired with AI and infrastructure plays. We are seeing underserved export markets emerge as fintech infrastructure opportunities, especially when compliance and onboarding are automated using AI. We're looking for fintech infra companies that can build end-to-end export platforms and monetize risk, data, or workflow layers. Margins, take rates, and use-case expansion (e.g., cards, treasury) matter.
. [2025-08-11] We are interested in B2B cross-border payments platforms combining regulated banking infrastructure with stablecoin settlement rails. Integration into local real-time payment systems (e.g., Brazil’s PICS) plus multi-currency named accounts and FX liquidity APIs creates high switching costs for enterprise customers. Key filters: regulatory moat, stablecoin + fiat settlement in one platform, and enterprise adoption in emerging markets. We are sensitive to heavy early revenue concentration.
meta.thesis: Stablecoins: Emerging Global Payment Rail and Financial Platform

meta.interest: New subcategory created for pipeline companies. Generated on 2025-09-19. [2025-09-22] We are tracking AI-native billing and usage-based payments infrastructure. Lark Payments (ex-Stripe engineers) and Lava Payments both address the gap in token-based and credit-expiring billing that Stripe cannot handle natively. Filters: AI-native usage models, developer-first adoption, stablecoin integration. Risks: crowded landscape (Paid, Metronome, wrappers on Stripe), early go-to-market strategies still developing, and need for clearer product vision to scale beyond initial developer traction.We are interested in next-generation billing and payments infrastructure for AI-native and usage-based business models. Paid.ai, backed by EQT and Sequoia, is the most credible team in the space (Manny Medina, ex-Outreach). Lava and Lark validate strong developer pain but lack the product depth and founder profile to win a winner-take-all market. Filters: AI-driven usage billing, stablecoin integration, agentic payment flows. Risks: crowded space (Paid, Metronome, Autumn, wrappers on Stripe), and weaker founders may get acquired acqui-hire style rather than scale.

meta.description: Deep Tech refers to startups and technologies rooted in significant scientific or engineering innovations that typically require long development cycles, specialized knowledge, and technical defensibility. These companies often emerge from advances in fields such as materials science, robotics, quantum computing, aerospace, energy systems, semiconductors, photonics, and synthetic biology. Unlike applications of AI, which may focus on data and software-driven workflows, Deep Tech innovations tend to rely on breakthroughs in physical systems, hardware, or fundamental science.
meta.interest: We are interested in companies that can apply novel deep tech solutions to real world problems in a scalable and profitable way. The founder would have to be exceptional and it would have to be in a vertical where we could add value.

[2025-08-19] We are interested in AI-driven materials discovery and self-driving lab concepts but recognize the high operational complexity in combining AI design loops with physical lab execution. We plan to track this space long term.

meta.interest: [2025-08-26] We are interested in AI-enabled architecture and construction design tools. Automating feasibility analysis, parcel compliance, and construction drawings could shift margins from cost-plus professional services toward high-margin software. Proprietary parcel/curb-cut datasets and early trust with developers are differentiators. Filters: defensibility of data advantage, ability to expand into construction documentation, and fit with standard modular projects.

meta.interest:
[2025-08-05] Really excited about robotics, especially in industrial settings where safety is critical
.

[2025-08-05] While we see potential in the home health or industrial robotics space, we are concerned about go-to-market challenges, vertical-specific sales processes, and the lack of commercially ready traction. Armstrong's dishwasher robot highlighted for us the difficulty of scaling robotics technology due to training complexity, despite its long-term potential.
.

[2025-08-05] We're excited about robotics and sensor-native foundation models as a wedge into the physical world. Archetype, building a foundation model for the physical world via multimodal sensor data, stood out for its enterprise traction and generalizable safety/compliance applications. We are particularly interested in platforms that abstract physical sensor data into programmable intelligence, as a path to robotics software scale. However, we are sensitive to round dynamics and will push for structured entry (e.g., discount to A or interim rounds).
.

[2025-08-05] We continue to prioritize frontier robotics with real unit economic leverage and software advantage. Veer Robotics (facade-cleaning robots) fits squarely in our robotics thesis: replacing high-risk manual labor with vertically-integrated automation that also captures unique inspection data. We're sensitive to capital efficiency, leasing models, and software data upsell opportunities. Preference for teams transitioning from semi-autonomous to fully autonomous over time.
.

[2025-08-05] We continue to track vertical robotics that replace dangerous and repetitive manual labor, especially where recurring leasing models and inspection data upsells can drive software margins. Hardware reliability, unit economics (multi-robot per operator), and defensibility beyond suction/IP remain key diligence points. Sensitive to lack of frontier VC traction.

[2025-07-29] We are actively tracking foundational infrastructure for robotics — from simulation platforms to real-time operating systems — as critical enablers of the next wave of physical AI. Startups like Foxglove and Xronos that abstract complexity in robot development and deployment align well with our belief in verticalized automation with software leverage..

Filters: ability to pair teleop data with autonomy training, equipment finance overlays (sale-leaseback, rental streams), and safety ROI for contractors.
.

We are particularly interested in platforms that abstract physical sensor data into programmable intelligence, as a path to robotics software scale. However, we are sensitive to round dynamics and will push for structured entry (e.g., discount to A or interim rounds).

[2025-08-11] While we see potential in the home health or industrial robotics space, we are concerned about go-to-market challenges, vertical-specific sales processes, and the lack of commercially ready traction. meta.interest:
[2025-08-19] We continue to track vertical robotics software layers for warehouse and manufacturing automation that replace engineer-dependent, rigid workflows with VLM/VLA-powered systems optimized for edge deployments. Modular integration with existing hardware can be a wedge. Filters: measurable throughput gains in dynamic workflows, industrial-grade reliability, and defensibility beyond commoditized hardware. We are sensitive to long sales cycles and risk of displacement by multi-purpose humanoids.

[2025-08-11] Really excited about robotics, especially in industrial settings where safety is critical
.

meta.interest: [2025-08-28] We are interested in AI-enabled architecture and construction design tools. Automating feasibility analysis, parcel compliance, and construction drawings could shift margins from cost-plus professional services toward high-margin software. Proprietary parcel/curb-cut datasets and early trust with developers are differentiators. Filters: defensibility of data advantage, ability to expand into construction documentation, and fit with standard modular projects.

[2025-08-07] We looked at companies like Solurian that are building AI-driven weather forecasting models targeting enterprise clients. While we find the team and technology strong, we have questions about their ability to scale enterprise sales and differentiate from competitors.
.

[2025-08-07] We discussed companies like Vadera Labs and others in AI-driven appraisals for niche markets (e.g., collectibles, industrial equipment). These markets are interesting to us, but we see challenges in validation, scalability, and market size that limit their appeal.
.

[2025-08-07] We are excited about AI legal tech platforms focused on negotiation and deal optimization for operators, not just lawyers. We prefer tools that replace legal process fees with revenue-generating AI services (e.g., automated term sheet negotiation, contract optimization for GCs and CROs).
.

[2025-08-07] We are tracking RPA’s evolution into deterministic AI agents in regulated verticals. We believe flexible, AI-enhanced RPA has near-term adoption advantages in compliance-heavy sectors like healthcare. That said, we are skeptical of RPA startups positioning as horizontal automation tools unless they demonstrate deep vertical traction and defensible infra advantages. Long-term, we expect agents to cannibalize many RPA use cases.
.

[2025-08-07] We continue to de-prioritize consulting-style AI tools and marketplaces. We passed on Thoughtly due to limited AI differentiation and an SMB-focused wedge that lacks breakout potential. We are not looking for low-NRR tooling unless it shows viral bottoms-up adoption or extremely strong sales DNA.
.

[2025-08-07] We are skeptical of standalone accent softening plays as venture-scale businesses. While useful in BPO and call center workflows, the long-term risk is feature-ization by larger AI voice stacks. Platforms that can generalize real-time voice personalization into broader human-AI interfaces may present a more compelling opportunity.
.

[2025-08-07] We remain skeptical of generic compliance tooling startups. Platforms that automate compliance-heavy workflows using AI agents could be interesting, but require deep vertical focus, robust infra defensibility, and clear monetization paths (risk/data layers). We are not investing in broad horizontal compliance SaaS.

meta.interest:
[2025-08-05] Really excited about robotics, especially in industrial settings where safety is critical
.

[2025-08-05] While we see potential in the home health or industrial robotics space, we are concerned about go-to-market challenges, vertical-specific sales processes, and the lack of commercially ready traction. Armstrong's dishwasher robot highlighted for us the difficulty of scaling robotics technology due to training complexity, despite its long-term potential.
.

[2025-08-05] We're excited about robotics and sensor-native foundation models as a wedge into the physical world. Archetype, building a foundation model for the physical world via multimodal sensor data, stood out for its enterprise traction and generalizable safety/compliance applications. We are particularly interested in platforms that abstract physical sensor data into programmable intelligence, as a path to robotics software scale. However, we are sensitive to round dynamics and will push for structured entry (e.g., discount to A or interim rounds).
.

[2025-08-05] We continue to prioritize frontier robotics with real unit economic leverage and software advantage. Veer Robotics (facade-cleaning robots) fits squarely in our robotics thesis: replacing high-risk manual labor with vertically-integrated automation that also captures unique inspection data. We're sensitive to capital efficiency, leasing models, and software data upsell opportunities. Preference for teams transitioning from semi-autonomous to fully autonomous over time.
.

[2025-08-05] We continue to track vertical robotics that replace dangerous and repetitive manual labor, especially where recurring leasing models and inspection data upsells can drive software margins. Hardware reliability, unit economics (multi-robot per operator), and defensibility beyond suction/IP remain key diligence points. Sensitive to lack of frontier VC traction.

[2025-08-28] We remain skeptical of generic compliance tooling startups. Platforms that automate compliance-heavy workflows using AI agents could be interesting, but require deep vertical focus, robust infra defensibility, and clear monetization paths (risk/data layers). We are not investing in broad horizontal compliance SaaS.

meta.interest: [2025-08-28] We are interested in AI-driven materials discovery and self-driving lab concepts but recognize the high operational complexity in combining AI design loops with physical lab execution. We plan to track this space long term.

meta.notes: Tools for robotics: motion planning, path planning, sensor fusion, control systems
meta.interest: [2025-08-05] We are tracking RPA’s evolution into deterministic AI agents in regulated verticals. We believe flexible, AI-enhanced RPA has near-term adoption advantages in compliance-heavy sectors like healthcare. That said, we are skeptical of RPA startups positioning as horizontal automation tools unless they demonstrate deep vertical traction and defensible infra advantages. Long-term, we expect agents to cannibalize many RPA use cases.

meta.interest: [2025-08-26] We are cautious on AI-driven penetration testing platforms. While enterprise demand for agentic pen testing is growing, the market is highly crowded, and broad platform claims lack defensibility. The opportunity may sit in coupling prevention with cyber insurance or success-based pricing models. Key diligence: depth of domain specialization in regulated industries, proof of superior detection, and monetization strategy.

Semantic approaches to prior art search and claims validation could reduce invalidation rates and augment existing legal workflows. Risks: consulting-heavy models risk commoditization, scalability is unproven, and pricing pressure may create a race to the bottom.

meta.interest: New subcategory created for pipeline companies. Generated on 2025-09-19. [2025-09-22] We are interested in AI-first drug discovery platforms that optimize for patient outcomes rather than target binding. Generative models that screen billions of compounds in silico can compress discovery timelines from years to weeks, particularly valuable in oncology, rare diseases, and immunology where datasets are small. Filters: patient-relevant hits, ability to bypass target-structure constraints, and integration with proprietary or exclusive datasets. Risks: defensibility depends on data ownership, validation beyond initial indications, and ability to translate scientific wins into commercial partnerships.

meta.thesis: Physical AI: Robotic Applications and Foundational Infrastructure
meta.interest:
[2025-09-17] We remain cautious on pure software layers for robotics; value capture may favor robot manufacturers. That said, robotics data platforms (Applied Intuition analogs, Roughneck) with proprietary datasets could be compelling wedges.
.

[2025-09-17] We are interested in retrofit teleoperation kits for heavy equipment as a wedge into autonomy. The unlock is legality (not voiding OEM warranties) and building proprietary operator-action datasets. Filters: ability to pair teleop data with autonomy training, equipment finance overlays (sale-leaseback, rental streams), and safety ROI for contractors.
.

[2025-09-02] Applied specialized robotics for tasks that are dangerous to humans. Some areas of interest are: inspection/maintenance, construction, oil & mining, etc...... [2025-09-22] We are interested in applied robotics in “dirty, dangerous, manual” refinery operations. Next Territory’s Geometra device automates bolting, reducing headcount and accelerating turnarounds with large cost avoidance potential. Filters: high daily downtime costs, entrenched founder-operator networks, standardized repetitive tasks. Risks: provisional patents, refinery environment durability, contractor disincentives. Early but promising—worth tracking.. [2025-09-22] We are interested in applied robotics in “dirty, dangerous, manual” refinery operations. Next Territory’s Geometra device automates bolting, reducing headcount and accelerating turnarounds with large cost avoidance potential. Filters: high daily downtime costs, entrenched founder-operator networks, standardized repetitive tasks. Risks: provisional patents, refinery environment durability, contractor disincentives. Early but promising—worth tracking.. [2025-09-22] We remain cautious on consumer AI hardware for kids. Outlier Humans and Kidco represent attempts to position AI as a “healthier” alternative to iPads, but history shows children’s hardware is highly competitive and subject to rapid commoditization. Filters: compelling product vision, evidence of true educational or developmental value. Risks: entrenched incumbents (toy companies, Apple/Samsung), difficulty building durable moats, and limited opportunities for Montage to add value in children’s consumer hardware.We are tracking teleoperation-driven robotics service platforms. Burn Robotics (ex-UC Berkeley/Apple) deploys teleop systems for BMW and biotech/logistics customers, offering quick adaptation to specific dexterous tasks versus brute-force training (Physical Intelligence). Filters: dirty/dangerous repetitive tasks, enterprise pilot traction, potential consulting-to-platform transition. Risks: services-heavy model, unclear TAM across fragmented use cases, expensive deployments. Worth tracking for potential evolution into a scalable industrial teleop platform.. [2025-09-22] We are interested in robotics platforms that lower adoption friction in high-mix manufacturing. Approaches that eliminate coding or retraining and allow rapid task programming address the primary bottlenecks in reindustrialization and reshoring. Filters: fit with persistent labor shortages, ability to sustain accuracy across varied tasks, and modular compatibility with existing factory infrastructure. Risks: vision-based approaches risk commoditization, technical durability must be proven across diverse use cases, and small teams face bandwidth constraints..
